comments.content: I would like to see more avenues for career development and cross training in state government. One specific idea I'd love to see is a more formal opportunity for employees to take temporary assignments or "details" with their own department or another department at the next step up on their career ladder. This is (or was) common in federal government and is a great way to give an individual some experience as a supervisor or team leader while also allowing a department to fill a temporary gap.

Outdated systems. Easier access to new technologies and platforms to streamline. Get outside of the paperwork, into automation. Yearly mandated training for employees for Microsoft Excel, Word, SharePoint, Adobe.

As a seasoned CA employee, I see waste/fraud in the use of licensed BU 9 classifications. I would recommend an audit of all BU 9 duty statements to determine if a license is actually required to do the job.   I say this because I have seen the state increase the use of "licensed" BU 9 staff when a license is not necessary to complete the work. DGS' Division of the State Architect, the Building Standards Commission, and the Office of Sustainability, as well as CalTrans previously hired non-licensed employees to complete the work that Does not  require a license.   However, in the past decade these Departments/Divisions/Commissions have stopped using classifications that do require a license. The problem is that the work required by these entities can be completed by a combination of licensed and unlicensed staff, but by hiring only licensed staff, the state is wasting hundreds-of millions of dollars.   A licensed architect/engineer gets paid (after benefits) $250k/year or more. An unlicensed person doing the work that doesn't require a license gets paid $150k/year. Multiply that $100k/year savings by the thousands of staff at DGS and CalTrans that are paid for their license but don't perform license-level work.  By hiring unlicensed staff to do the unlicensed work, there is also an opportunity for the state to recruit and maintain staff.   But STOP paying licensed BU 9 staff to do work that non-licensed staff can do. It will save the state at least 1/2 a billion dollars.

Accounting/Trust: Gobs of inefficiencies with a chain of command that doesn't know the details when I bring up better ideas. HQ Does not  understand what we do in office at institutions and policies contradict each other. We waste thousands of sheets of paper per month on statements when they could go out on the tablets. We spin our wheels answering GA22s for balance inquiries for hours a day when again, make it available on the tablets. We print monthly court checks for mandatory payments from IP accounts, however each court seems to be entered several times with a slightly different title (ie: Fresno US District vs. Fresno USD) and so multiple checks print out to the same exact place. This is wasteful and time consuming. Correct the duplicate entries so that one check prints per court. Also, SOMS pay sheets mostly print ONE IP per page. This is so wasteful and makes for lots more signing and takes up more room in storage. When asked about at HQ, no one knows how it works so it cannot be fixed. Someone has to know.

I think a great way to make California's government more efficient is to allow those that can to work from home as much as possible. This saves the state money, it often allows for a better quality of living and saved money for the worker and doesn't seem to impinge on productivity as has been shown since working remotely since the pandemic. Those in management would do well to understand a happy workforce is a productive one, and forcing people into working conditions where they have to spend more money to work will not help. You can entice better workers and keep those that are doing well by offering this kind of incentive that so many are doing away with. The primary job of the government should be to serve its people.  Working from home does this, it helps everyone in this State.

I think longer tenured middle management positions are unwilling to adopt new tools or technology that would assist in efficiency. While the adoption phase of new technologies may be inefficient at first, once people get used to them, it may make completing tasks much easier. I think this would require more top-down enforcement and accountability standards from the executive directors and branch chiefs.

Procurement process. Sometimes needed items for efficient work can take 5-8 weeks if you are lucky to get even if you are out or plan ahead. What about the items that you cannot plan ahead for? There is no way to get things quickly, even paper, pens, cleaning supplies, and other needs. This often results in people paying out of pocket for supplies. There should be a way to get needed supplies when they are needed. The procurement process is redundant, too many unnecessary steps to aquire easy things.

California needs to stop throwing money into it's useless GenAI platform. The data it was trained on is hilariously outdated and a huge waste of money. The use of GenAi makes State workers lazier and its impacts on the environment are vast.

Economies that are structured with a primary goal of concentration of wealth have unintended negative results such as poverty, isolation and scarcity and ideologically based conflicts.  One of the ideas to diversify economic security is a fairer flat tax for all (removing exemptions). This flat taxation idea also helps secures housing and jobs for all thru subsidies offset by the flat tax and creates a liquid cash flow (capital) to help maintain the economy as we shift to more sustainable systems not dependent so much on non-renewable resources with are finite. By broadening the definitions of success we can address phenomenon like corruption, toxicity, hoarding and emphasize values like sharing and improve empathy and caring generally. As we share intelligence and apply it to these common goals people experience and learn from the experience of others so problems that threaten societies are minimized as the cooperation crosses typical socio-economic and other common isolating conditions that threaten an optimal healthy form of democracy and threaten environmental sustainability.  The results are predicted to offer a more sustainable way of life where greater forms of equilibrium and harmony may thrive and the diversity of our intelligence more positively be expressed and celebrated.

The state is composed of various departments that are very small in size and often must contract out to provide obtain basic services internally or externally. These contracts can include interpretation/translation, website maintenance, a/v services, cabling, etc. Sometimes staff are stretched thin in smaller offices with various responsibilities because there is not enough personnel to cover issues that a team in a larger organization would do. There is so much time spent in bringing on external providers in addition to the cost of services as well as recruiting for staff turnover due to burnout. The state could better coordinate services across departments under a certain size reducing costs and providing adequate support for staff and the public.

One issue I have consistently encountered is the challenge of working with state procured contractors, especially in programs that involve direct public service like case management.  In my experience, onboarding and training contractors can be time consuming, and often their staff do not fully understand program policies or the scope of work. This can lead to inconsistent messaging and confusion for the Californians we serve. Many of these vendors are also based out of state and may not fully grasp the unique needs of our communities.  I believe we should explore bringing more of this work in house. For example, having state employees handle case management could improve consistency, accountability, and transparency. It would also allow us to better control outcomes, reduce excessive billing, and build internal capacity by developing staff skill sets.  While contractors can play a role, I think a more balanced approach with a stronger in-house presence would ultimately lead to better service delivery and public trust.

Bureaucracy. Red tape. Lack of ways of measuring and awarding productivity.  Lack of organizational efficiency - too many layers of management (all the way to agency level and beyond), creating unnecessary communication and miscommunication issues, let alone time wasted digesting all the communications.

Across two state agencies, poor communication has consistently hindered productivity and morale. In one agency, management prohibited cross-unit dialogue, slowing progress and isolating teams. In another, annual surveys repeatedly flagged communication as the top issue, yet leadership insisted on injecting themselves in every conversation or discouraging communication with other units and divisions. Instead of seeking answers from the sources, managerial direction has focused on the interpretation of resources that often prove incorrect. These decisions negatively impact morale, cause frustrations in a job that would otherwise feel ideal, and reminds of the axom that people don't quit jobs, they quit managers.   Managers often lack subject matter expertise, causing delays and confusion. Many openly promote a â€šÃ„Ãºfake it till you make itâ€šÃ„Ã¹ mindset, prioritizing their own job security over the work required to excel when serving the public. The solution is simple: empower staff to communicate directly and collaborate freely, hire a strong human resources team to handle all of our regular issues, and reduce the layers of management. We can build a more agile, informed, and customer-focused workforce.

hiring staff- it takes 3-6 months there are so many layers that are redundant  being able to let go of staff is also a challenge- poor performing staff leave one divsion for another and the hiriging staff are not made aware the employee was a challenge

I would like to standardize templates and basic duties across agencies and departments.  Having to relearn the job that you were already doing elsewhere because the culture is different is inefficient.  Provide a standard writing style guide for Contracts and Procurements across the state.   Invest in a statewide procurement solution that all departments have access to. A way to track work, control who edits, and route for approvals. Maybe even tie it into the signature processes.  Something that would work for an analyst working in a small shop under 10 people as well as the large departments of thousands.   Ensure consistent and appropriate levels of training. This promotes the transferability of skills and ensures a baseline for promotions.  Provide information on how analysts can successfully promote through the ranks. Workforce development stops with Executive Assistants, Secretaries and Office Technicians. Analysts and other employees would like assistance and a clear, step by step process for how to promote within the state.  Offering Interviewing training as a part of the career growth.   Offer advanced analyst positions above AGPA or Research Analyst that Does not  require moving into management. Often people are subject matter experts, but that Does not  always transfer into leadership capabilities.

DGS Procurement rules that are same for different organizations.  It should be different for organizations that are buying papers/pens etc vs organizations that need to buy specialized equipment or instruments.   Procurement rules are not effective and efficient and  hinders other departments from doing their job in a timely manner.

Environmental and financial stewardship. Our Sacramento area freeways are crumbling under the weight of too many vehicles generally and specifically during business hours. Invest in urban public transportation. Locate State offices near transit hubs. Stagger State worker schedules to minimize our impact in congested areas.

Forms, processes, systems, and software are extremely outdated. Suggesting the State maybe have one large contract with Microsoft or a vendor for supplies that way we all have access to the same quality of resources.

In my 17 years experience, the CalHR rules have become so rigidly enforced that our organization has many problems because CalHR doesn't allow flexibility for us to optimize operations. We end up keeping many positions that could have been consolidated, as certain work gets deprioritized. We used to be able to move positions around to meet division needs, but now we have to request a new position. We are constantly losing high quality staff because strictness of HR rules enforced means high quality candidates often fall outside the narrowness of the HR rules.  We would be so much more effective and efficient if CalHR could allow the flexibility they used to give to allow us to determine what are needs are and move around resources to meet them. Everything has become so top down in recent years, with no opportunity for discussion to figure out how to get the department's needs met. So this feedback tool is appreciated.

Seems like travel is a issue - would be more streamlined if there was a travel department to handle all travel for all staff.  As it is now, there are people who don't want to attend work conferences due to the issues around knowing what form to fill out for what portion of travel. If this was centralized it would cut down on errors and really speed up the entire process.  Just leave reimbursement in the hands of individuals, and have them call the "travel dept" to arrange the rest!

Problem: We have really smart employees that spend years doing their job, but their institutional knowledge often gets stuck or siloed, so when they leave, or the work increases beyond their capacity, it's hard to step in to do the work. I think some solutions could include better documentation protocols, with staff dedicated to upholding them (i.e., making sure our network and SharePoint folders get insane, which they always seem to), and staff time to document/communicate procedures and innovate ways to improve processes.

California has many managers within the state government. However, there are few leaders amongst the managers from my viewpoint. And the staff of these managers have no voice. This causes both the management and teams members to stagnate and lose sight of serving the public; eventually many work environments become stressful and toxic.    My idea is to one: give the voice to the team members as this forum does, but allow them to rate their managers or supervisors yearly. Two: measure the amount of turnover on a yearly basis under the tenure of a manager or supervisor. Managers, could be put on yearly training assignments where they can serve in different state organizations. Based on the metrics after 2 or 3 years use the metrics to determine if a manager is effective. If a manager doesn't prove to be effective after this tenure they should be released, re-assigned or demoted. If they are measured to be effective, can they can then be assigned to a permanent position but can be re-evaluated after another 3 years.  This is the basis of my idea. Currently, when a person occupies a managerial seat, there is very little to prevent them from becoming a bottle-neck to progress and there's nothing the team can do about this. I've seen millions of tax payers dollars go to waste because of this scenario. I have seen many managers who are micro-manage out of fear and ignorance and the staff is at their mercy which is a moral killer.  There is no perfect system but we need new direction

We waste a lot of money on mental health with 1:1 observation status. Currently when an i/p cites that he/she is suicidal we send them to an alternative housing unit temporarily for up to 24 hours before placing them or transferring them to a MHCB or back to the yard. This requires multiple nursing staff to watch and round for this task. INSTEAD: pull them out, strip down their cell and place a CO on them for the observation. 1. a CO is a cheaper overtime than nursing. 2. this would cut down on the secondary gain from the observation and the more behavioral i/p will think more about what they are doing before eliciting a CIT. This way we can pay more attention to the truly SI/SA i/p.

Housing! Housing! Housing! As a civil servant, I do not earn enough money to even afford a 1 bedroom apartment where I live. It would be amazing if the state could build more housing for low-income people who work full time, like me!   Allowing people to telecommute is good for the environment, reduces traffic, and increases a department's ability to fill positions. I don't telecommute myself, but I think telecommuting should remain an option. If more people could telecommute, that means they can live anywhere. Spreading out the demand for housing outside of the Silicon Valley, Sacramento, and Los Angeles may help decrease the overall prices in those already congested areas.   The state already owns a lot of land. Build work centers (hoteling?) for state employees in different areas where housing is cheaper. Build employee housing at places like Napa State Hospital to attract good candidates and keep them. We have a high turnover and our employees commute from all over. Our campus is beautiful and we already have our own police and fire department. Build little cottages that employees can rent for a decent price!  Or, provide housing subsidies for state employees who do not earn enough to afford rent in high cost areas.
Empower leaders to take mild risks so we don't get stuck putting all our eggs in one basket. Smaller moves

I have seen a lot of wasted taxpayer money due to the lack of modern technology and practices, as well as the state's refusal to create a space to save millions of dollars by allowing their employees to have a right to work-life balance. Many city and county agencies are far more advanced, provide healthy work-life balances, and provide proper training to management. The little bit of training provided is toxic and our managers are taught poor leadership behaviors. We as adults, are treated like children and are not allowed to have a work-life balance because management uses unfounded information to justify saying no to its employees. We have been told by our management that we are all replaceable and are not valued as employees and this is very disheartening. For our commissioner to feel that way about his staff is demoralizing. This message from the commissioner and management is not going to motivate us or drive performance. As a state employee, I previously valued my work, my team, and the contributions I make every day. Mutual respect would create a healthy work culture, but unfortunately, this attitude from management is creating the opposite effect. No state agency is exempt from the law and exempt from transparency.

Talent retention is a problem as many private sector jobs have higher compensation.  Here are a list of solutions: 1. Market rate compensation 2. Flexible work hours 3. Get rid of the RTO mandate 4. Put work from home into law 5. State worker compensation should not be a political issue

When a construction project requires technology, that technology is out of date or obsolete by the time it is purchased for the project.  A new system needs to be put in place that separates technology from the project so the latest technology can be procured closer to the time it will be installed.

One thing I have noticed after working for CDCR for over 25 years is that they put unqualified people in administrative jobs.  An example would be: instead of hiring someone with a business/accounting background to be in charge of "Business Services", CDCR hires someone that worked their way from up from an officer or secretary to run that department.  This happens in the medical department also.

A problem I have noticed is that time is not taken to research and investigate problems and wastes that are barriers to improving processes. One of reasons for this is because managers and staff are overwhelmed with the number of improvements that can/need to be made. A solution to this is to create a Process Improvement Priority Tool where we list the process that needs improving and score it based on the impact it has on customer/patient care and if we already have a policy or procedure in place to mitigate the adverse impact. Based on the scoring we can determine what process/issue to tackle first.

I think the State could benefit from standardizing the processes that all departments follow. Consistency is key and there are many missed opportunities for efficiency and greater effectiveness in our shared processes. Areas to consider include onboarding of new State hires and the hiring process. Of course, a key piece of doing all this would be to make sure that we have one efficient and effective process for everyone. Some changes to the current way of doing things would likely be required.

The websites are hard to navigate for the public. Try to make a user friendly website or have a calling center so that the public can contact someone that can direct them to the appropriate department.
It sounds basic, but staffing is vital to do the job. Personnel is policy. Without adequate clerical staff, our unit is paying Engineers or Scientists to do data entry.

I've been a teacher with CDCR since 2016. I never in my lift have seen so many "hands" being involved in the easiest of processes. For instance, to get student prior transcripts sent to us, I have student fill out transcript request, hand that form over to our OT, the OT then emails/mails the form to the said school, the school sends transcripts back. If student is a graduate, I fill out another form to request their removal from education, DocuSign it to my supervisor, and the supervisor then requests the drop from the institution's assignments officer.  Attendance works similarly. Within 15 minutes of class starting, I fill out a form showing absent students and email it to our education officer. Education officer spends his time calling each IPs housing officer, if they can be reached, to verify if IP is coming to school or not, then the education officer notes "A" time, "S" time, etc ... and returns to me to fill out SOMS attendance.  I feel there is so much wasted energy and time that could be used elsewhere to make our programs run more smoothly and with less time to process things.
I am a problem solver. I would focus on what is working and what needs to be grown positively.

The primary problem is low salary scales. This isn't just my opinion: The California Legislature's Bipartisan Fiscal and Policy Advisor released a report with data that shows average monthly salary figures have continued to fall behind market averages even calculating for inflation, and top step for salaries has also been in decline. An employee will abide great discomforts if they're compensated handsomely. But, that same employee will pursue other employment if neither salary nor working conditions reach respectable levels. Getting "paid in sunsets" is insufficient to recruit and retain top talent. Field staff are repeatedly told we're the most valuable members of the organization. But, HR, finance, management, and safety policies loudly declare the true narrative which contradicts all niceties.

In private sector, folks expect that gen AI and other LLMs will make work more efficient therefore contracts are baking in 1-5% reduction year over year in allocated costs. We often bake in inflation but don't expect efficiencies from new tech etc when we reprocure. I would recommend that our contract template includes an expectation for efficiency year over year from our vendors.

The primary problem I'd like to address is modernizing our technology and streamlining processes. Coming from private sector, I was shocked to find the very manual processes due to  budget constraints and inability to invest in system to streamline processes (e.g. HRIS)

Hi. It is not a secret that in the next 5 years, technology will evolve at a much faster pace than ever before. Is our beloved State of California ready for serving our future generation? Do we know what that future may look like and what the demands are? It is certian, that If we do not plan for it now, we all lose. Thank you.

The biggest issue during my 5 years with the state as someone in IT is seeing computer illiteracy amongst employees. I often hear people say "I'm not a computer person" whenever they come across something they don't understand or have an issue with. I don't think this is an acceptable mentality when over 90% of their job is on the computer! I'm not asking them to troubleshoot everything but I would like to see some effort in at least Googling how to fix minor issues like adjusting a view in Outlook or their display settings.  Here's a few other common things I've encountered.  -Not knowing how to shut down a computer or the difference between shutting down, restarting, sleep, and closing the lid. -What file explorer is and how to navigate network folders. -How to use the search (Windows key) to find stuff. -How to connect to the WIFI and VPN.  That is why I think we need some sort of basic computer literacy exam before people can apply for a job. Maybe add it as a component in CalCareers.  Another big problem I see is paper waste. We spend so much money on printers/faxes, and supplies when most things could just be a PDF. In my dept, I think we spent over a million on a filing system that can be moved electronically.

I know this won't be a popular opinion, but I'd like to see LLMs integrated into workflows with the objective of reducing labor costs over time. I wouldn't want to see it displace anybody already employed, I'd like to see a workforce reduction through attrition. I'd want departments to put teams together that consist of employees of all levels who go through every workflow function to determine what can be automated or streamlined with an LLM. I wouldn't want it rolled out until it was tested by folks not on the original team. I know for my job, about 40% of what I do could easily be automated.

Hiring.  Why is it that I can look at a list of interview candidates, and guess with good accuracy who will be offered the position- before the interviews occur?  Why is the new contractor for equipment maintenance coincidentally the husband of the supervisor?

A mentor program for first year or new employees who come into state service. Learning how the state functions, how long it takes for certain tasks or forms to be implemented can be daunting and confusing. Having a mentor or buddy to walk new employees on what to expect would be a great way to increase turn over and have employees engage with each other in meaningful ways.

The need to push forward on something that clearly isn't working or needs more time in development. Hitting the pause button, while measuring implications, isn't a sign of weakness, it's a sign of self-reflection, accountability, and the want to do things the right way. So many times we have duplicative efforts and efforts that just aren't working, but rather than taking the step back we keep trying to fit the square peg into the round hole.

We need digital (mobile-optimized) data intake. The state has SO MANY forms (applications, recertifications, licenses, grants, etc.). Californians should be able to do most of their interaction with the state on their phone (this will make backend data more accurate, too). Their identity should be known at the state, so programs across agencies should share their respective data on the backend so a Californian doesnâ€šÃ„Ã´t have to enter the same data every time they interact with a new program.

Yesterday I attended California's 175th Birthday Block Party. I thought it was an awesome idea for the Capitol to host that type of event for the community. It would be great if we could continue the tradition and invite state employees along with the public with more advance notice/communication. It would be a fun way for state employees to network with each other and the public as well as promote all of the great services/hard work we provide. I think it is a great way to boost morale and pride working for the state. It would also be nice to have a speaker or a special guest come out as well to showcase California's talent!

As a manager with many years of experience, the first problem I would address is hiring. People are our biggest asset. The process has improved over the years with online exams but there is still a long way to go. It's difficult to understand how to get a job with the state. Many people apply for positions that they are not eligible for. This takes HR and the hiring managers time to weed through applications.   Fortunately, my department now has a recruitment team to help with the process. Maybe each department should have one or share one.

We in State service focus on implementing programs that distribute funds to solve a problem.  Distributing those funds are often under a regulatory time constraint.  The internal culture leaves little room to perform the Project Controls used in the private sector to hold grantees accountable.  Project Controls track the money and schedule progress to hold stakeholders accountable.  The current culture is to assume everyone is honest and playing by the rules, so we can hand out the funds and solve problems "efficiently" by skipping accountability.  But leaving standard Project Controls out of the process isn't an efficiency; skipping a step in basic project management is a problem.  It is an invitation to some to commit fraud.     This isn't a "poor performance on the part of some people" issue.  It is a cultural habit in our institutionalized processes, maybe because we don't have to show profit and loss.  Incorporating the principles of Project Controls in our contract agreements with grantees - mostly invoice format requirements - is a part of the solution.

Using technologies that were burgeoning 10-20 years, while not keeping up with modern stacks. Promote courses that allow staff to stay up-to-date with innovative technologies and provide them access to them.

Document/form management is a statewide challenge that could more effectively be coordinated centrally. In the previous century, everything went through the Office of State Publishing, and the State Library had catalogued copies of everything that was published, but now each agency has its own content management system and publishes to the web with no centralized coordination. Retrieval largely depends on private 3rd party services. Index each web address and tag with metatext; leverage librarians' expertise to structure a retrieval system facilitating public access. Track revision dates, ownership, and language translations within the same platform. Use AI document translation with a common lexicon, have a disclaimer and feedback mechanism to prioritize review (e.g. vital docs), ID bad translations, recommend improvements. Also flag items past a certain revise date. At present we have active standard forms owned by agencies that no longer exist and historic documents posted that pop up when searching for current policy. It is not always clear what is current and what is outdated. Systems like WorldCat and GoogleBooks provide models, and there could also be a concierge function for the public to punch in what they need and receive instructions along with any necessary forms and guidelines (perhaps compiled by AI and verified by human staff, moving to spot checks as effectiveness of the tech is demonstrated).

I think homelessness is a huge issue. There are many different organizations that work to provide support but no one actually making significant change. We need an overarching solution. People don't become homeless overnight, and they won't get out of it overnight. We need to have a 2-pronged approach. 1st - before someone becomes homeless, we need to have a program that would allow them to access grant funding to catch them up and keep them from becoming homeless. It's far less expensive to catch someone up than to pay for all of the services they will need once they are homeless. 2nd - once someone becomes homeless, we need the ability to get them into mid - term (1-2 year) housing with wrap around services to ensure they can have their physical/mental health needs addressed, get or increase their employment, find childcare if necessary, and save money. During this time, they should also have access to financial literacy education, job training, and if needed, drug treatment programs. Waiting until someone has exhausted all options and is sleeping on the street before "helping them" by providing them 30 days in a motel, is only perpetuating the problem and keeping people in poverty.

Working with limited federal and state funds and maximizing the services we can provide. I suggest making all backend/support/non-customer-facing roles telework first, to reduce expenditures on office rent and utilities.

A single tool for Emergency management, a tool that has been approved and aligned with all agencies to be the true source of real time data.

Is there a State translation service available? If there is, it needs to be easier to find and if there isn't... well there should be one. A problem I'd like to raise is the importance of providing timely and meaningful feedback. Strong managers use the STD 638 to offer the truly earned feedback, where mediocre managers often rank everyone as "M" and provide little, if any,  constructive feedback there or in day-to-day interactions. For those who have been over-achievers all of our lives, to have a mediocre manager provide this is frustrating and off-putting. Encourage managers to work hard on these as this engagement will motivate staff, support professional growth and ensure that high performers feel valued. Less effective managers tend to provide only average or generic reviews, even for excellent employees, without offering guidance on how they can advance. This lack of feedback discourages staff and can hinder development. Additionally, promotions should be based on demonstrated leadership qualities rather than circumstance. A stronger vetting process is needed to ensure promotions go to those who consistently model dedication and performance. HR should also allow and encourage higher rankings for employees who truly give 110%. When staff exceed expectations but their reviews do not accurately reflect their effort, it creates deep frustration and drives talented employees to consider leaving for agencies where their contributions will be recognized. By strengthening both the feedback process and evaluation system, the organization can better retain top talent and truly promote a culture of excellence.

I think efficiency is a huge part of things for me. Whether this means streamlining systems or revisiting process steps, I've long felt the impact of circuitous actions which, especially in repetitive tasks, limit the potential for more meaningful task completion, learning, and even have negative impact on employee engagement and morale.   Proper education in evolving with technology and developing less complicated means to accomplish required tasks enables big changes to be handled in a more incremental manner, which, in turn, allows more adequate training and mitigates the inherent aversion to change by offering what appears more like help, rather than a potentially overwhelming or burdensome addition/change to one's workload or processes.  This ultimately improves job satisfaction, thus improving morale and even reducing costs as work completion times not only reduce, but the ease and desire for employees to complete more work increases. Supplementing this with relative and engaging training invites staff to become more invested in not only the evolution of the process, but the overall objective(s) of the larger department/industry.

In most cases when the employee's doctor is recommending telework as a reasonable accommodation, departments will do anything to delay or deny telework as a reasonable accommodation. Departments have continually been allowed to ignore and violate the ADA, EEOC, and FEHA policies and regulations and oppose doctor's recommendations for appropriate reasonable accommodations.   As a whole, the state needs to hold departments accountable for following appropriate policies and regulations pertaining to reasonable accommodations. More timely processes and procedures should be implemented. It is unreasonable to allow each department's EEO unit/section 90 days to investigate themselves, while not providing an employee with a disability their recommended reasonable accommodations. A more consistent and streamlined approach needs to be developed to help support California's employees with disabilities to better provide them more equitable and inclusive work environment when working for the state.

We are a large and diverse state. One size Does not  fit all. However, nuanced policies are extremely difficult to put on paper, create black and white rules, and thus subject to abuse. We must accept that there will be some who will be left out by policies we write, but also appreciate that a well drafted policy will help far more than will be left out. A poorly drafted policy, while perhaps well intentioned, often creates more waste and confusion than solutions.

CalEPA's Boards, Departments, and Offices (BDOs) routinely require regulatory data to be uploaded to public databases annually, or within days of certain events (e.g., a rain event). For example, the State Water Board operates the SMARTS database wherein industrial permittees upload data throughout the year to demonstrate compliance with the General Industrial Storm Water Permit. Other BDOs operate similar types of databases.   The state should strongly consider a system to compare the applicable numeric values in the self-reports against the regulatory thresholds. Automatic notices could be issued to the permittee or a report could be generated and provided to the enforcement unit of each BDO. This would improve compliance and accountability, while also benefitting human health and the environment. The opportunity for facilities to "hide and wait" for enforcement would be diminished.

Recruitment and retention of state peace officers is harder than ever over the last 10 years.  Many police agencies have adjusted to the times and now allow officers to wear well groomed beards and display tattoos that are of good taste and not objectively offensive.  However, the California Highway Patrol has not allowed tattoos to be displayed nor male officers to have beards, all for the sake of tradition.  Our modern culture has grown to accept both as acceptable in the workplace, and in fact, makes officers more relatable.  Many communities may be able to relate to an officer who has tattoos, especially younger people.  As the melting pot of the United States, many foreign cultures co-exist in California and universally respect male officers with beards as being elders with serious life, and job experience, particularly when they see gray in the beard.  This makes them more willing to listen and being compliant with an officer.  It's already permitted for religious exemptions, i.e. for Sikh officers.  It should be permitted across the board for all officers.  This may seem like a non-issue to someone not in law enforcement, but other agencies have noticed higher levels of recruiting and retention by allowing tattoos and beards.  It is also a huge morale booster and allows officers to express themselves as individuals and humans, rather than as de-humanized, monotonous, faceless agents of the government.  I would like to see State Personnel Board force this issue with CHP

I would recommend shifting toward PLAIN LANGUAGE communication across all state agencies, making information clear, simple and accessible to all Californians.  Alongside this, we should invest in practical resources like website tutorials, FAQs, or short instructional YouTube videos, that guide people step by step filling out forms and accessing services or joining public online meetings.

One of the challenges that needs further analysis is the replacement of staff when they move on from State Service. In most cases, departments are unable to fill vacancies until after the position becomes vacant. This leads to an exodus of knowledge and expertise from the department that is not easily replaced as it often takes years for an individual to become fully proficient in their role, establish connections with others and gain career long learning. While this practice may lead to salary savings, it creates a knowledge deficit which then leads to efficiency loss until such time as the individual staff person learns the position and becomes proficieint and beyond. If departments had the ability to hire replacement staff while the existing staff person was still present, the knowledge transfer would be more streamlined, and the institutional knowledge can be much more easily passed on to the new staff member. An in-between step might involve the creation of desk manuals for new staff to access however these will not necessarily impart the same level knowledge as the in person tutelage of the out-going staff member.

At the same time, we are told that we need to provide the same, if not higher level of service to the public. This leads to existing staff being worn beyond thin working multiple jobs and duty statements that do not accurately reflect their workload. The situation just feels like a crash happening in slow motion with me as a rank-and-file watching it happen with little that I can do about it.  If I had a magic wand that could easily change things, I would focus on ramping up hiring and retention. I understand there are budgetary considerations, but it is not possible to recruit and retain long term employees if our district Does not  have any growth opportunities for seasonal staffing. An overreliance on seasonal employees seems to be the crutch that my department relies on, forcing interested seasonals to endure years of attrition and competition before landing a permanent position.  By retaining more long term employees, they will have a better chance of learning how state systems work and managing them efficiently and effectively. Longer term, this will be more sustainable than relying/spending on technology centered "efficiency" campaigns.

One of the reasons this happens if SPB has a rule that examination results are kept private, so there is no way to know the exam results of others who have taken the same exam, and it becomes extremely difficult to prove when others rig and/or cheat the system.  Another reason is the heavy reliance on job references, which seem to these days be more important than actual work experience and meeting job qualifications.  Get a hold of all of the dishonesty and restore actual merit in the merit system and you will have better, more qualified, reliable, knowledgeable and more efficient state employees. I am tired of having to work for "the kids" of former executives who do their absolute best to ensure their next of kin get out of doing actual work.

It can feel like departments are operating in silos, keeping information to themselves instead of working together. I think focusing on standardizing processes and building a more open, collaborative culture would significantly improve how effectively we function as a state.

PROBLEM: I work at the North Coast Regional Water Quality Control Board in the Cleanups Unit.  We transitioned to a paperless file system  back in 2006 when the State began requiring reports/data to be submitted and uploaded to the Geotracker database. There are still 100s of existing folders, reports, etc. (one estimate was that our unit's file room contains 1/3 of a mile of paper). Environmental pollution cases are unique: we're required to keep records of all sites, closed or not, in case land use changes in the future (also, it's the law). We routinely have PRA/FOIA requests to pull files for consultant review, and more than 75% of the time they'll ask us to scan and email them.  Our region is also vast- some of these consultants and landowners live 6 hours away from out office, and some have physical handicaps that limit their mobility, so we try to oblige. But actually taking apart a file, scanning it, categorizing it, and uploading it is extremely labor intensive. A small file will take a few hours, but even a medium sized one requires one or two days (the scanning is rapid, uploading and naming is laborious).  SOLUTIONS: 1) hire dedicated admin staff to do this work, 2) subcontract it out to a bonded document scanning service. BENEFITS: 1) Reduced labor costs for professional and admin staff 2) improved public access for these records 3) potential to upload to AI for detailed summation and analysis. Thank you,

If the goals for the Engaged California project include to find challenges that undermine our ability to work efficiently and effectively, and to discover ways to better serve the people in our state, it doesn't make sense to take virtual work (or RTO) off the table for discussion. Additionally, this is supposed to be a deliberative democracy forum, as such reasoned positions are valid and should not be limited. Overall, as a state employee that is in a hybrid position working both in person and virtually at times, it is important to validate the values that virtual work affords state employees, state agencies, people in our state, and the state budget. It is also important to see how virtual work solves for problems in inefficiency and ineffectiveness, and can help to solve for ways to better serve the people in our state.   A primary problem right now is the position that virtual work shouldn't be part of the Engaged California discussion to find solutions to problems (because it is supposedly doesn't "stay on topic" - see Engaged California's "Sharing Guidelines" ).  It makes no sense to talk about workplace efficiency and effectiveness, and to talk about better ways to serve the people in our state without considering talent management, workplaces, work mediums/channels, and work spaces. A set proposed solutions include opening this forum to the topics of virtual work, talent and workplace management, and work conditions.

Telework, when possible, is the biggest issue.  Telework works.  Consolidating office space (combine multiple departments/agencies into spaces) will save money, as per the state auditor's report. State Workers working remotely will also save money by reduced commutes and the associated climate change savings, which used to be important to our state government, and by putting money back in their own communities, versus being expected to prop up the communities around the office buildings their departments are located in.  It also increases employee happiness, and as a long-term state worker who has been in offices with both great morale and awful morale (both prior to the availability of telework, and not related to telework at all) happy employees make for more productive employees.  Telework works, the state has shown that.  Reversing course will only hurt the state going forward.

As a state employee, that is focused on cyber security related issues, the primary problem I would like to address is the state not properly addressing Data Sovereignty. As it stands a majority of the data collected, generated and used by departments is physically hosted and stored with third-party companies. Companies who have issues of their own with keeping themselves out of their customers data. Although we have contracts governing how they handle this data contracts alone are not enough to protect citizens from the fallout should these companies' data centers become compromised. The sole responsibility for governing and protecting California citizens data rests with the state and its civil service. My solution to this problem would be for the California Department of Technology restart it's program to create a state cloud. The technology to do so has come a long way since it's last attempt and there is opportunity to recruit recently laid off tech workers into the civil service to support such a project as well as opportunities for more smaller local technology companies to engage in contract work to support the open-source software that will underpin it all. This would ensure that California data is protected and guarded by Californian's as well as California leading the way in Data and Technology governance.

I believe there should be a universal intranet site with agency-specific and subject-specific subsites.  The main site could include spaces for disseminating information (e.g. statewide policy), posting training and job opportunities, hosting webinars, sharing news on projects and subjects of statewide interest, and collaborating/idea sharing.  This site is a good start but access to a statewide community should be automatic, not opt-in. I also believe the state would benefit greatly from further standardization of web/software design and a collaborative community of engineers. (e.g. having templates for commonly needed software, like procurement, inventory, appointment scheduling, marketing/newsletter, learning management, certification tracking, mobile apps, etc.) Agencies could then customize templates to fit their unique needs. This could make software more accessible and affordable, encourage development of the state IT workforce, reduce reliance on private sector contracts, and create a more universal user experience, reducing the need for training when someone changes agencies. Lastly, I believe data required/used by multiple agencies should centralized to reduce errors/discrepancies and time spent on data entry. A first step would be auditing existing databases to identify what data is being collected by multiple agencies currently.

The state is spending billions each year on construction, purchase and maintenance of office space. By allowing all positions that can be performed remotely to be filled by remote workers, the state could save California taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars a year on office space, equipment, and IT services, while simultaneously expanding the applicant pool for state government positions, and advancing equity by opening up opportunities for career advancement to candidates living in economically disadvantaged areas of the state.

A primary problem I would address is the culture within the State departments. A lot of upper management have an authoritarian complex and seem to go out of their way to punish or reprimand their employees. This is leading to less employee retention and higher stress among departments. If the state wants to begin to hire a new generation of employees, the authoritarian style of management needs to change. Younger generations will not want to be treated the way most state employees are being treated now. I currently do not have ideas to solve this problem, but I feel this issue will continue to get worse as our workforce continues to age and retire.

Rebuilding our local and statewide economies.    - Strengthening our education system    - Creation of new products, markets, businesses    - Creation of newer good-paying jobs and careers    - Lowering taxation across the board    - Creation of educational financial aid programs to help people who financially struggle to make it possible for them to achieve a good-paying career.

I don't believe it's fair to be charged for parking at a state-owned parking garage. I feel like I'm being charged unnecessarily, just for going to work. Can state garage maintenance be included in the CA budget? That way workers don't have to pay for parking directly. At least the financial burden gets spread amongst all taxpayers.

While I understand that this is not where we are supposed to discuss work conditions, ignoring them is a disservice to all of California. Addressing these issues helps to ensure a happy and healthy workforce which is key to good customer service, performance, and efficiency. Workers need to have their needs met in order to perform at their best. The state should strive to provide the best work environment possible to each of it's employees. This should not be a one-size-fits-all approach as every human has different needs. Some people need more support than others. Some require more guidance. Others need less. The state should also do more to understand neurodivergence within the workforce as it plays a part in the needs of each individual. This is also true for each role, not classification. Each role has different requirements of technology, tools, communication, supplies, etc. Tailoring things to the individual and the role they fill will greatly improve efficiency, productivity, collaboration, communication, quality of work, etc.

The return to office mandate for state workers is an unjustified waste of money.  The recently-released telework audit coordinated by Josh Hoover proves this.  State workers who can telework should be allowed to telework full-time.  This would save the state hundreds of millions of dollars annually in office leases and would increase the state's ability to recruit and retain qualified employees.

Too much and sudden involvement of AI/Gen-AI in state; and this is taking away our old school lifestyle. Nothing seems real or genuine.  Soln: put a pose on too many incoming AI/Gen-AI requests. These requests are overcrowding our tradition workspace and workload.

Primary problem is communicating complex ideas and regulations that we work on to the general public. We need to figure out better communication channels and messaging, as well as ways to better process and organize the voluminous information that our state agencies process.  Possible solutions: exploring AI tools and technology to help organize, summarize and message complex ideas and processes to the public.

There is a lack of available technical asynchronous training, including in programs used daily by employees, such as Microsoft programs. Many of us, including legal staff like myself, receive large amounts of data that could be more easily summarized and analyzed with advance knowledge of Excel and Microsoft Office programs. While Excel would greatly streamline my work, including summarizing data quickly, I have yet to receive Excel training because there are no Excel trainings available online, nor have these been available when Iâ€šÃ„Ã´ve checked for over a year.

The primary problem that I see are executives overloading lower management and analysts with projects and unrealistic goals.   I also feel like we as State Workers are not appreciated by our own government and we are used as the patsies when things go wrong. We end up being the ones to suffer when the government fails to meet their goals. Billions are being diverted for other programs yet State Workers get their pay threatened constantly by going over budget.   We need to be appreciated by our executives and our own governmental leaders. These are the issues I hear amongst coworkers.

Primary problem: I would like to see more Leadership Training.  I understand there are mandated hours of training (and have taken them) which covers management resposibility, performance management, understanding union representation etc.  I think tangible leadership skills would also be helpful.  Leading a team (of any size) can be overwhelming and staged training that covers various skills and topics would help any leader. Solution:  I would have a learning path that needs to be completed in one year - since that is typical probation period.   The learning path would have a series of trainings that cover soft skills as well as the content currently covered.  I also think having a buddy that you could stay in contact with and bounce ideas off each other would be helpful so it is an ongoing type of training.

Lack of training in all staff, including management.  Abuse of time because documentation on staff takes years, and years, and is a lot of work.  Promotion of incompetent staff, because they are great talkers.  And because their opf  is clean due to the fact that managers do not want to be the bad person.

I work in one of the many Legal departments. I receive in service of process. When someone sues the department and its employees, it is codified in law that each person/department gets a copy of the document.  Just last week, I had an individual name/sue 30 different people. So per law, each one needed a copy of the over 500 page document.  We need to change the law so that we can take electronic service. That way instead of piles and piles of paper (where I scan in only one copy) and distribution happens electronically. What a waste of paper and human effort. I have heard the law needs to be changed. Okay, let's change it! This effects every legal department in the state and also anyone else who serves papers on anyone in any law suit.

Big Idea: Streamlining Student Internships at State Agencies  Right now, if a college student in Californiaâ€šÃ„Ã®say, someone attending CSU Fullertonâ€šÃ„Ã®wants to do an academic internship at a state agency like California State Parks, they face a long and complicated process. Their university has to negotiate a legal agreement (a MOU) with the agency, often involving lawyers on both sides. This process can take months and discourages students and agencies from even trying.  My proposal: The Department of General Services (DGS) should create a blanket MOU that covers academic internships between all California public college systems (Community Colleges, CSU, and UC) and all state agencies. This would eliminate the need for each university and agency to negotiate separate legal agreements every time a student wants to intern.  Agencies would still define the details of each internshipâ€šÃ„Ã®like duties, schedules, and supervisionâ€šÃ„Ã®but the legal framework would already be in place.  This would: - Make it easier for students to gain hands-on experience in public service. - Reduce administrative burden for both colleges and agencies. - Create a clear recruitment pathway for state agencies to identify and develop future talent. - Expose students to careers in public service, helping build a stronger, more diverse pipeline into government work.
Consistent training across multiple offices within the same department.  Greater collaboration to reduce redundancy

I believe a standard employee/department directory for every district should be created and kept up to date so that when outside agencies, vendors, the public, contractors, etc. are asking for the correct contact-it can be found easily on Onramp.

Many of the processes used at my department were not built with a focus on efficiently serving our customers. As such, there are often multiple wasteful and non-necessary steps both employees and customers are â€šÃ„Ãºrequiredâ€šÃ„Ã¹ to take before a customer transaction can be completed.
