It has happened on several occasions that when an improvement is introduced it fails to receive the support that is needed for successful implementation because some members of management fear change and/or feel that they cannot devote employee hours to implementation and testing. I believe systematic and proven process improvement techniques (like Lean Six Sigma, PDCA, Total Quality Management, etc.) performed by state-employed process-improvement specialists that have the support and resources that can be provided by department heads and agency-level management could act to improve inefficient processes across that state.

We are unable to hire personnel, we are very short staffed.  The people that are employed are not qualified, and to terminate a uncooperative employee is not possible, making it very difficult for the hard working committed employees.  The uncooperative staff are rewarded and treated better than the employees who pick up the slack and work hard and are at work all the time.

Primary problem that I'd like to address is how to work around the forte of employees rather than their weaknesses. Employees need internal trainings to sharpen the skills they already have to make it more effective and strong. Roles should be given on the basis of their expertise and the bandwidth depending on their job duties. Mark their personal and professional achievements using different platforms.

I see that there is a huge waste in spending with the ISUDT program within CDCR.  The counselors that are hired are only required to run their counseling classes Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.  Tuesdays and Thursdays they do not hold classes so they can "write case notes." However, you can see these counselors using their time to take breaks, walk around the institution for exercise.  I urge the state to evaluate the data and see if this program is genuinely cutting down on the substance abuse problem amongst the inmate population.  The funds for these programs would significantly cut expenditures for CDCR.

The contracting process is broken. Californians want government to have easy to use online tools, one-stop-shop permits, data access portals, and to use the latest technology to make people's lives better. Both IT and non-IT contracts are cumbersome and require navigating gate keepers who do not understand agency needs. If a project is deemed IT by contracting personnel, my agency will simply not move forward. If a contract gets flagged for the PAL process with CDT, the contract is dead, and we will never resubmit. Money lasts 3 years, and the PAL process can take that long, leaving no time for the money to be used on the intended project. Further, getting non-IT contracts through DGS is time-consuming and cumbersome with little added value, decreasing the time for the money to actually do work.   My suggestion would be to loosen up contract oversight on the frontend, actually provide training to staff, and provide more resources for auditing and enforcement of contract rules and ethics on the backend. In this way, SME staff will be trained on contract creation and execution (which is currently not the case) and can quickly get money out in flexible ways, taking advantage of as much of the 3 year money lifetime as possible, while knowing that they must strictly adhere to contract rules or their money will get pulled back and contracts will get cancelled. If you want staff to move fast, and use technology, this has to change.

Simplify TAX for everyone! Ideally, all taxes should be administered by ONE agency and only ONE phone number for help! Please get rid of all these fancy tax agencies in this state! Many people leave California because they are taxed on things like how much oxygen they consume on a daily basis!  Create a NEW agency called California Department of Tax! ONE phone number for taxpayers to call and get answers to anything related to TAXES and FEES.  Make it EASIER for businesses and individuals to pay their taxes. ONE PAGE tax returns!  This will create efficiency and effectiveness and make the 45 million Californians happy!

Agencies have shared contractual needs. Would like to see a repository of common services statements of work templates in DGS library as an appendix or  via a link in the SCM that can be utilized at different agencies understanding there still may be a need for customization to include specific logistical instructions for various facilities, frequency of service and other items.  E.g. for pest control, trash/compost, fire extinguisher testing/certification, IT server room cleaning, etc.   Would like an organization chart with email/phone information at various agencies available for state employees to access for networking and collaborative problem solving.  An activity or program may be new to an agency but is not new to another agency, example a new grant program authorized for an agency to implement that has not managed grant program funds for years or previously at all.  Having the ability to ask how a different agency has set up a program recently and leverage existing operating procedures would be more efficient than starting from scratch.
Ineffective leadership, antiquated resources, funding issues.

I feel a big problem is the lack of collaboration with other state agencies about processes that need improvement. I feel like we work in silos, and it would help us all tremendously if we could share more information with other agencies to find out ways that may work better. One solution could be to have forums where people with similar responsibilities/titles could meet and help one another.

As a long time, State employee and manager, I would like to see a more streamlined approach to purchasing and hiring.  The processes are constantly changing and many times when there are "Statewide contracts" (an example would be tires), there are not enough "official locations" to make the contract viable or easy to use. We could be more efficient if DGS would delegate that authority lower to each department or at agency level.  Same with hiring processes.

I've experienced this in the private sector also, but for some state employees that have worked for the state for decades, there is often little room for change. There is a sense of "we've always done it this way," which can be challenging and create extra work for others. For someone like me, who goes around those who aren't happy about change and makes the change anyway, a solution could be more encouragement around the work we do and the improvements we can make can be a boost of morale. Also, we can normalize change and not make it a daunting or annoying thing in the workplace.

Some of the laws and procedures that have been implemented with the intent to fight corruption and waste have been counterproductive and have in fact increased waste. This is a complicated subject that is beyond the scope of a simple comment and will require involvement with the legislative process.

Coming from the military into the state, I have noticed a lack of proper training and materials to aid in job support, roles and responsibilities, as well as understanding the state rules/policies. When I met with HR, I explained being new to state and was handed a document with links and was told to go research with no explanation.   For my job, I was told it takes about 1-2 years to grasp even the lingo in our unit, let alone how we operate. There were no procedure logs or training as there isn't any turnover for the last employee to show a new one what it was they did. The structure seems a bit unorganized and the chain of command doesn't seem to be followed.

Working in a human resources division, the largest complaint I have been given from the public is the lack of communication. I find that many NEW to State service candidates apply to multiple vacancies and do not receive any feedback or notice if a job was closed. I believe communication from hiring manager(s) needs to improve; whether a candidate interviewed or not, they should be receiving an auto-email explaining why they were not chosen. There are options for this in ECOS (from CalHR), so I am not sure why it is not being used (at least in my Dept). I feel this may alleviate some of the frustration from those wanting to join State service.

The amount of taxpayer money spent on state office space is staggering, especially considering most work can now be completed remotely. Even without considering working conditions or what's best for the state employee (although I think telework supports those, too), utilizing telework dramatically reduces overhead costs with no negative impact to work product. Many departments reported improved efficiency during the pandemic with 100% (or near 100%) telework. Telework also improves recruiting, as departments aren't limited to candidates local to Sacramento and can effectively and efficiently hire from across the state. With finances growing tighter and tighter every year, telework is an easy way to address budget shortfalls in a way that unions and employees will also support (as opposed to layoffs and furloughs). I could talk about management inefficiencies, obtuse procedures, and other issues all day long, but this inefficient use of taxpayer dollars is the problem which has the most obvious and straightforward solution that will have the most significant immediate impact.

I think there is problem in understanding the relationships between taxes and the public services they fund. I feel the state should work on a marketing campaign to help Californians better understand this relationship and the value we all receive from the public programs in the state.

I believe if we invested in the development of a user-friendly CDTFA cellphone app for business owners, CDTFA could 1. Gain more transparency with the business owners and 2. Become more efficient the collect sales taxes for the state.   For example, my collectors and I meet with the business owners with collection accounts at the field office and during our field calls at the business locations. Almost all the business owners we meet do not use a computer or own one and therefore, rely on their cellphones conduct day-to-day business activities like accepting a payment through Zelle for the sale of a t-shirt or food, business banking, creating a sales invoice to give to a customer, using Square to swipe a credit card payment, etc. Specifically, I would like to see that a user-friendly cellphone app is developed for CDTFA to make it easy for a business owner to register for a sellerâ€šÃ„Ã´s permit, make changes to the account (like an address changes or adding/closing business locations), pay sales taxes/state revenues, eFile tax returns for up to two locations, show past due taxes owed, setting up payment plans, and making a request for tax relief from penalty, interest, etc. I specifically would like this app to cross-register the business owner for other licenses and fee accounts under the authority of CDTFA.   The interface of this app should be easily uploaded to CDTFA's database in real time or within 24-hours. Add a chat function using AI to answer basic questions.

The primary problem I would address is homelessness. I have several ideas to fix this problem, and they can be implemented in stages. First and foremost, make it easy to build affordable housing. Recognize that homelessness is a housing problem.   2nd, Prioritize the people who just slipped into homelessness and have potential and will to come out of it. Help them to come out permanently and join mainstream.  Right now, I serve as board member for HART of Folsom, and we are proud to have reduced Folsom's homelessness by 10% this way. 3rd, go deeper and help people that are homeless longer and probably will never come out.  Build shelters with services for them and make rules to humanely require them to take those services. Those rules might curtail some of their freedom, but they should know that it's cost to pay for not being able to come out of homelessness by themselves.   Finally, to do all this work, encourage and fund the non-profits directly from the state so that the rules are uniform. One positive side effect is that more non-profit jobs are created this way. Each city and county having its own rules and managing and distributing funds will only create more red tape and confusion and dysfunction. Re-organize the current machinery and people work under one state agency with simple and uniform set of rules.
I feel there should be less "red tape" to cut to solve issues.  Permits take time to be ratified because of lawyers and special interest groups

As a former Federal Employee, and current state employee, I think there is a gap when it comes to holding employees and leadership accountable to their responsibilities. While there are a ton of dedicated and competent employees, there are also those that utilize the protections afforded to public employees and those in unions to not meet even minimum potential. To solve this problem, I think we should ensure that employees and supervisors are being periodically checked in on. I have had three roles within the state government since 2021 and have never had a performance review or worked with a supervisor on a plan for trainings or moving forward in my career. I also think supervisors should undergo a 720 degree review - where they are appraised by their supervisors, employees, and themselves.

Nursing is grossly understaffed. Upper management is rarely if ever in the clinics engaging with their medical staff. Nepotism and favoritism are rampant. An SRNII told an LVN the other day that she should stop bringing up issues regarding safety because she, "won't get hired when she gets her RN license, because management doesn't like people bringing up issues." Education relies too much on staff to train new employees. There's zero continuity in the clinics, so that plan is fraught with issue after issue. Custody has become too complacent in regard to safety and security. A resident in C Yard was caught with eleven diabetic syringes/needles. That particular resident gets insulin twice a day, so they were able to acquire all those needles over a period of time. Residents bring their tablet to the pill window and in the clinic. The tablets aren't allowed to leave the housing units for obvious reasons. A patient reported to an exam room to complete their appointment with me this week with a hot cup of coffee. I didn't notice he was holding it until we were in the room together. The porters/residents in our clinic are allowed to "clean" without anyone directly watching them. The porters/residents are given access to areas they should never be given entry to.

The California's Bureau of State Auditor provides recommendations for improvements to California government. California's budget would be better balanced and taxpayer's money would be used more efficiently if the governor and state officials followed the recommendations and implemented better practices.

The modus operandi at the state is "quick fixes" and treating the symptoms of problems rather than getting at the root cause. So, we end up with broken systems covered in Band-Aids rather than systems that work.  We need to really look closely at what is happening and make changes- slow down to speed up. First fixing our support systems and then our mission systems. Usually, you would want to spend all your time and effort on the mission, but you cannot make the mission process (why the department exists) better if the process to make the mission process better is siloed and broken. For example- if it takes 2 years to fix a typo on an external form, how do you expect to do any larger improvements for the customer experience or streamline the process for internal stakeholders? This is the reality of my current job with the State.

I've been a state employee at the prison for more than 10 years. These are the most common problems we see there.   -Overriding Inmates to a lower level when they don't deserve it. By overriding youth offenders, medical Inmates or non-violent offenders to a lower-level causes disruptions in positive programing. Inmates should be placed into an appropriate security level based on their security points only. -Promoting and Pushing the Suboxone program to receive time off makes Inmates that would normally not take it, sign up for the program just to get time off or sell the Suboxone in the dorms/housing area. Don't give time off for the program and you will have only the Inmates that really need it on the program or don't give out Suboxone because by the time they get to State prison they should have already gone through withdraws and be clean. -The overuse of medications to Inmates is out of control. We are no longer a prison but a medical facility. Most Inmates take medication in hopes to get time off of their sentence or get on Social Security when they get out. Thousands of pills are spit out or sold in the dorm. Have doctors not medicate Inmate so easily.

We can make California government more effective by implementing long term telework. With digital systems, agencies can process requests, respond to the public and complete requests faster. In emergencies, public health crisis, or severe weather, employees can safely and efficiently report to their home offices without additional risk. Cost savings for California is clear when telework is implemented. Agencies save money on buildings, equipment, utilities, office supplies, etc. Telework will eliminate daily commutes, thus improving air quality in California, reducing risks of accidents, and giving employees time back to improve their mental health. California can attract top talent by offering this perk.

The current status of government limits the methods that can be employed to improving California.  We have to be open to alternative methods and do not dismiss ideas because "we do not do things that way around here".  Most of the leadership in the departments and agencies are career bureaucrats.  They only know one way to address issues.  When a new approach is brought up, it is almost always shot down before it can even be explored.  This happens because people in leadership are afraid that if they verve from the normal process, they will lose their jobs.

Frivolous, unnecessary spending and paralysis by over-analysis. Too many levels of bureaucracy, and too many opinions to seek out before decisions can be made.   Centralize purchasing authority within departments for furniture, IT, and office supplies. Every unit Does not  need to keep their own stockpile of supplies, nor control possession over certain state assets.  Roll out a "How-To" process to teach people how to digitize files so we can eliminate expensive rent spending for paper file storage. Maximize the use of office space by configuring smarter.  Yes, use Lean Six Sigma principles. We teach it. Let's actually use it.

Funding and more transparency. I feel money goes in the wrong places sometimes and we have people making decisions that have no idea what works and what doesn't (coming from CDCR). I also think more schedule flexibility would be nice for state employees, as I often feel time constraints in my day-to-day life that are unnecessary and could be preventable with more flexible schedules.
I would say management in CMF Does not  communicate well and needs to follow policy more.
Homeless. Convert malls to shelters and help people get back on their feet.
Lack of efficiencies and funding for efficiencies.  It would be nice if we had a modern, centralized system for reporting and tracking that would cut out the back and forth that slows things down

Within the department I work, we experience a significant amount of extra workload from secondary and tertiary duties. These are duties that fall completely outside of a person's duty statement and go far above the standard "5% of other duties as assigned." clause in the duty statement. This includes assignments such as EEO coordinator, Skelly officer, Peer Support Specialist coordinator. It seems these types of assignments get handed to 1 or 2 people instead of split among several to lighten the burden.

We lack uniformity in knowledge and training. We need more of the philosophy of "when you learn, teach". Open communication, current and updated training, updates to critical work equipment are essential.

The primary problem I would address is inconsistent/unfair in the hiring practice. For example, mid/senior management with no prior state service experience, skills or knowledge matching the job description getting the job whereas internal candidates are overlooked. I understand there are some positions that are elected positions in the state. Majority of the positions are filled with who you know basis rather than merit based.  The idea to resolve the problem is to have regular audits on hiring processes for all the state departments. There should an oversight by the California State Auditor's Office.

As a state employee for more than 15 years, I would like our employer to highlight the work state workers do with the focus on changing the public perception of State Workers.  We work hard for the citizens of California and often dedicate unpaid time to ensure those we serve are receiving the care and attention required to prevent disruption in the services we provide.  In times of extreme hardship, we work long and exhausting hours without complaint.  State workers are of value to California.  A campaign to lift up the heroes that work for California, highlighting the  great workers that support our state is needed.

Make telework flexible and based on operational needs as determined by first line managers and staff. A one size fits all telework model (RTO 2 or 4 days per week regardless of operational need) is not appropriate for most technical positions that can be done effectively from home, is wasteful of taxpayer dollars, and decreases employee morale, all of which impacts public service. Having a one size fits all telework model is also bad for retaining talent. We need technically proficient staff. If talented staff can telework full time with better work life balance and greater physical and mental health, and be treated with respect in managing their workload in the private sector, why would they opt to work for the state where we are treated like we can't be trusted to manage ourselves or allowed to telework based on operational need?  Who wants to work for an entity that frames the need to be in office as "because teachers and janitors have to report to a job site everyday so should all other state workers". This approach disrespects the life choices that folks have made regarding their career path. A teacher and a janitor are aware that their work involves reporting to an offsite office daily, whereas technical careers or those that do not require direct face to face with the public should be allowed to telework based on the operational needs of their position. Flexible telework fosters trust, is just as effective for collaboration, and more cost effective.

I have seen many issues such as management not having good leadership skills, or knowledge of the duties their employees should be doing, along with bad organization and communication. All managers should be trained and efficient and regularly evaluated on this matters as it can really have a negative affect on staff.

As a new employee of my Department and in this State, I had a large learning curve.  I didn't totally understand my role and responsibilities until a person with my same job in a different District came to our office to train me and shadow me while I worked.  Before, it was very hard to understand due to the amount of unique acronyms used by the state even within guidance and or training.

If possible, I would implement a system that allows official business with the public to be conducted safely through email, text notifications, and secure online portals. This approach would provide instant communication, ensuring that more people especially those without stable mailing addresses can be reached quickly and reliably.  By transitioning to digital access, the public could view, complete, and submit forms electronically rather than relying on traditional mail. This would significantly reduce printing and postage costs, streamline processing, and enhance overall efficiency.  Number of the individuals my department serves are transient due to unstable housing, making electronic communication far more effective than mail. Allowing technology to replace paper-based processes would not only save government resources but also give the public greater control and faster turnaround times when submitting information. Primary Problem Sales and use tax regulations are complex and often contain gray areas. True expertise usually comes from auditors who have dealt with specific, real-world applications of the law. However, there is no easy or safe way for auditors to share their knowledge across the department. Getting clarity on how to apply a regulation often requires layers of approvals, and managers may hesitate to elevate questions up the chain. This slows audits, wastes staff hours, and delays clear guidance to taxpayers.  Proposed Idea Create a safe, department-wide collaboration channel where auditors can directly share and discuss regulation questions with a large group of experienced peers. For example, an internal email group or moderated forum could allow auditors to submit questions and receive input quickly, without having to navigate multiple levels of approval. Faster feedback would reduce audit hours, improve consistency, and give taxpayers clearer answers sooner, all while fostering a culture of shared expertise and professional growth.
